title: United Nations Reform and the Rebuilding of Failed States: A Study of the Formative Stages in the Development of the UN
abstractText:
This project will analyse the development of a new United Nations organ – the Peacebuilding Commission (PBC) – during its first 16 months in operation. Constituted in June 2006, the PBC’s primary function is to ‘marshal’ the international community’s resources (financial and intellectual) to prevent states that are ‘emerging from conflict’ from slipping back into civil war. 
 
Stakeholders have expressed considerable confusion concerning how the PBC will work in practice: how it will relate to the principal UN organs; whether the PBC will be able to exert influence over UN agencies working in post-conflict countries; and whether it will evolve doctrine that can guide multilateral decision-making on the conduct of peacebuilding missions.   

The project will contribute to debates among practitioners through empirically detailed assessments of the PBC’s performance during a formative stage in its development. It will also contribute to scholarly understanding of how international organisations evolve to meet challenges imposed by an increasingly interdependent world.

Through field research at UN HQ (and in post-conflict countries on the PBC's agenda), the project will chart the emerging contours of a key element of UN reform, designed to address one of the most pressing tasks facing the international community – the reconstitution of failed states.
